nodes.text: Teacher quality has substantial causal impact on elementary students' standardized reading and math achievement and can be identified using panel data with teacher fixed effects

Use of panel data linking students and teachers across years in two contiguous New Jersey elementary districts, including student demographics, up to five annual standardized test scores per student, teacher identifiers and teacher attributes
There are large and statistically significant differences across individual teachers in their impact on student test scores
Teacher experience has a positive and statistically significant effect on reading outcomes, even controlling for teacher fixed effects

Common classroom-level variables (class size, average prior class achievement, split-level classroom indicators) do not predict student test scores in these districts once teacher and student fixed effects are included

Teacher effectiveness is positively correlated across subject areas (positive pairwise correlations between teachers' fixed effects across vocabulary, reading comprehension, math computation, math concepts)

Estimated teacher fixed effects explain a nontrivial share of test score variance: upper bounds ~5.0-6.4% of total variance and lower bounds ~1.1-2.8%, implying teachers account for an appreciable fraction of policy-relevant variance
Policymaking implication: improving teacher quality can meaningfully raise student achievement and policies should consider performance-based indicators rather than relying solely on credentials
Data are from only two similar New Jersey districts, so external generalizability to state or national distributions of teacher quality is limited
Identification relies on assumptions including an experience cutoff (no additional effects after a chosen experience level) and limited persistence of inputs; violations may bias estimates

Estimation strategy: linear regressions of student test scores with student fixed effects, teacher fixed effects, school-year effects, controls for time-varying student and classroom variables, and a polynomial in teacher experience; standard errors clustered by student
Magnitude evidence: a one standard deviation increase in teacher quality raises reading by ~0.20 standard deviations and math by ~0.24 standard deviations on a national standardized scale (NCE)
Magnitude evidence for experience: about 10 years of teaching experience raises reading vocabulary and comprehension by ~4 NCE points (~0.20 sd); math experience gains are small or not significant
Empirical evidence shows class size and classmates' previous average test score are statistically insignificant predictors of student scores in these regressions

Pairwise correlations of estimated teacher fixed effects across subjects are positive (vocabulary with others ~0.16-0.32; other subject pairs ~0.46-0.67), indicating cross-subject complementarities rather than tradeoffs
Policy recommendation: shift some emphasis from hiring/compensating solely on credentials toward measures that reward demonstrated student learning gains or other performance-based measures
